section.p: The HPE Helion OpenStack Monitoring service leverages Monasca, which is a multi-tenant, scalable, fault-tolerant OpenStack monitoring service.
This document describes the Monasca service and contains the following sections:

li.xref: Differences Between Upstream and Helion OpenStack Implementations

section.title: Installation
section.p: The Monasca service is automatically installed as part of the HPE Helion OpenStack installation.
No specific configuration is required to use Monasca. However, you can configure the database for storing metrics as detailed in the Monitoring Configuration document.

section.title: Working with Monasca
section.p: Access to Monasca is available through the Web UI (Operations Console), command-line interface (CLI), or the low-level REST API.
The Operations Console (Ops Console) is designed for Helion OpenStack Administrators to have a web-based UI that they can use to operate and manage the Helion OpenStack environment.
To determine which IP address to use to access the Operations Console you can use this command from your deployer: grep vip-HZN-WEB /etc/hosts
The output of that command will show you the VIP you should use. It is listening over port 9095 on that VIP, so you can use the following syntax to access it:http://VIP:9095
section.note: The credentials for your admin user account can be changed. See Keystone Configuration for more details.
section.p: For details on the use of the Operations Console, see Operations Console Overview
For users who prefer using the command line, there is the python-monascaclient.
For details on the CLI, including installation instructions, see Python-Monasca Client
If low-level access is desired, there is the Monasca REST API.
Full details of the Monasca API can be found on GitHub

section.title: Service Alarm Definitions
section.p: Helion OpenStack comes with some predefined monitoring alarms for the services installed.
Full details of all service alarms can be found here: Service Alarm Definitions.
When alarms are triggered it is helpful to review the service logs. Details on how to use the logging UI built into the Operations Console can be found here: Logging Interface
